discussion.content:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/undo.htm#ADMIN13741
16.7.1 About Managing Temporary Undo
Temporary undo records are stored in the database's temporary tablespaces and thus are not logged in the redo log.

choices.E: No redo and undo records are generated for temporary tables.
choices.A: Undo records for temporary tables are stored in a temporary tablespace.
choices.C: Undo records for temporary tables are stored in the undo tablespace and logged in the redo only for those sessions where temporary undo is enabled.
choices.B: Undo records for temporary tables are stored in the undo tablespace and logged in the redo.
choices.D: No redo is generated for the undo records belonging to temporary tables.

choices.A: The MEMORY_MAX_TARGET parameter is automatically set to 500 MB.
choices.E: The instance does not start up because Automatic Memory Management (AMM) is enabled but PGA_AGGREGATE_TARGET and SGA_TARGET parameters are set to nonzero values.
choices.C: The value of the MEMORY_MAX_TARGET parameter remains zero for the database instance.
choices.D: The lower limits of the PGA_AGGREGATE_TARGET and SGA_TARGET parameters are set to 90 MB and 270 MB respectively.
choices.B: The PGA_AGGREGATE_TARGET and SGA_TARGET parameters are automatically set to zero.

discussion.content:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMQS/GUID-E6784230-0A0C-443D-8537-36FFA08A7E75.htm#ADMQS12039

In a text initialization parameter file, if you omit the line for MEMORY_MAX_TARGET and include a value for MEMORY_TARGET, the database automatically sets MEMORY_MAX_TARGET to the value of MEMORY_TARGET. If you omit the line for MEMORY_TARGET and include a value for MEMORY_MAX_TARGET, the MEMORY_TARGET parameter defaults to zero. After startup, you can then dynamically change MEMORY_TARGET to a nonzero value, provided that it does not exceed the value of MEMORY_MAX_TARGET.
With MEMORY_TARGET set, the SGA_TARGET setting becomes the minimum size of the SGA and the PGA_AGGREGATE_TARGET setting becomes the minimum size of the instance PGA.

I agree with the answer: A and D:
A: if you omit the line for MEMORY_MAX_TARGET and include a value for MEMORY_TARGET, then the database automatically sets MEMORY_MAX_TARGET to the value of MEMORY_TARGET. https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/memory.htm#ADMIN11200
Basically, MEMORY TARGET AND MEMORY MAX TARGET is identical

questions.question_text: Which statement is true regarding the startup of a database instance?

choices.B: Uncommitted transactions are rolled back during the startup of the database instance after a shutdown using the immediate option.
choices.D: Media recovery is required when the database is shut down by using either the immediate option or the abort option.
choices.C: There is no difference in the underlying mechanics of the startup whether the database is shut down by using the immediate option or the abort option.
choices.A: The instance does not start up normally and requires manual media recovery after a shutdown using the abort option.
choices.E: Instance recovery is not required if the database instance was shut down by using SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATE.

discussion.content: By using RMAN copy, you can move the storage

choices.B: by using the Database Upgrade Assistant (DBUA)

questions.question_text:
Your production database uses file system storage. You want to move storage to Oracle Automatic Storage Management (ASM).
How would you achieve this?

The HR user executes the following query on the EMPLOYEES table but does not issue COMMIT, ROLLBACK, or any data definition language (DDL) command after that:
//IMG//
then opens a second session.

HR -
Which two operations wait when executed in HRs second session? (Choose two.)

choices.D: SELECT empno,ename FROM employees WHERE job=’CLERK’;
choices.A: LOCK TABLE employees IN EXCLUSIVE MODE;
choices.C: SELECT job FROM employees WHERE job=’CLERK’ FOR UPDATE OF empno;
